thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Baked Gnocchi with Arrabbiata
comments: Terrific recipe! I wish I’d had a chance to take a photo before it vanished. Not only tasty but stunning enough to serve guests…when we can invite them over again. Plus it’s easy to prepare, even with homemade gnocchi — the biggest challenge was remembering to bake the potatoes ahead of time.
HI, can Xanthyum Gum be used instead of tapioca starch?
Oooh this is like all my favorite things in one *drooool* Can you make this in one large casserole dish rather than the individual ramekins? If so how big should it be?
I often use sunflower seeds in place of cashews, it gives a very similar result!
Hello! I love this and have shared with a friend. She is allergic to c.oil. What would you sub for in the mozzarella sauce? Thank you!
Just made this and my kids and loved it. Thankyou! Just wondering, do you think the cheese is freezable? I have HEAPS leftover

Just made this the other day and it’s really good! I used jarred sauce so I can’t speak to the sauce recipe. Funny, I was a little worried I’d done the mozzarella wrong because it was liquid, and I thought it would just mix into the gnocchi and make a mess, but it worked perfectly! I could taste the coconut oil a little bit, but I didn’t use refined coconut oil which I think would make all the difference in the world. Thanks for this recipe!

I’m going to give this a shot. It looks fantastic!
However, I’m wondering if there is an alternative to the cashews for the mozz sauce? I am deathly allergic to all nuts…and I have yet to find a vegan cheese that actually is stretchy AND tastes good. Being new to eating this way, and being a huge cheese lover previously, it is the one thing I miss from “the Before”.
This looks incredible Eva! I need to try this like ASAP! Love the bubbly sauce and crispy cheese MMMMMM

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Naan
comments: When I made this naan, I found out I was completely out of salt! I tried subbing 2 tsp of very salty mushroom powder and wound up with such a delicious umami flavor. I couldn’t get enough! Figured I’d note that here in case anyone else wants to try adding mushroom powder to their naan as well.

This naan was excellent! Everyone loved it. It was so soft and tender. I really like that you use weight for baking, it makes me more confident your recipes are going to work. Thanks so much for sharing!
Can this Naan recipe be made with gluten free flour?

I have a question! We have a pizza stone and a barbecue, and sometimes make Italian pizza in the barbecue (it’s made by high heat and the pizza cooks in a couple of minutes – it’s how they do it there). Can I use the barbecue in the same way to cook the naan? Thank you!
Obviously submitted before reading.  That should be *lakanto
I omitted the oil and used lake to monkfruit sweetener in place of the sugar. It still turned out amazing. Thank
Do you flip it while baking?

Hi, thank you for the recipe. This Naan was so easy to make & so delicious, airy & flavourful. I made my dough yesterday, using coconut plain yogurt, as it was the only vegan yogurt in my supermarket (very small rural town). I put it into the fridge overnight  & rolled it out & cooked it tonight on a pizza stone.
I doubled the recipe because I am taking them to work tomorrow (I am catering a work luncheon for 13 people). I made some large & some small (the small ones are perfect for scooping up the red lentil curry & the sweet potato, chickpea & spinach Dahl I’ve made as well) I can’t wait to get feed back from my work colleagues.
Cheers from Australia

This turned out great! I didn’t have enough yogurt to do 1 full cup so I inverted the measurements for water and yogurt (1/2 cup instead) and it worked out perfectly. So pillowy! I let it rise/ferment in the fridge overnight. I also pan-fried them on a cast iron rather than heating up my oven.

Well, since I was completely blind to the fact that you included measurements by weight, it seems clear that it’s me who made some kind of big mistake! I guess I’m just jealous that everyone else seemed to have made it with such wonderful results 🙁
The bread turned out, but it’s more of a “flatbread” than naan. I’ll try again – thanks for the great recipes!!

Yes, I measured and used white flour. I measured by volume, as there was no weight indicated in the recipe. I did whisk the dry ingredients together as per the recipe. The yogurt was not thick/greek yogurt – I easily poured it into my measuring cup. The only thing I can imagine is that I zoned out while adding the flour and added an extra cup – it’s the only thing that makes sense, regardless of how nonsensical it sounds 🙂
I’ll be baking the bread shortly, and I’m sure it will work out well with the extra water I added.
Thanks for getting back to me.

I’ve just prepared this dough as per this recipe, adding the 1 cup yogurt, 1/2 cup warm water and 3 T melted butter. It is SO dry! I can’t believe that you achieved the sticky, moist dough in your pictures and in your directions with only this amount of liquids. Is it possible you’ve made a mistake? I had to add at least another 1/2 cup of water just to get this dough anywhere near the pictures and your description. Please clarify – thanks!

Hey! My naan tasted great but I think I still must have done something wrong. I don’t have a stone so I used the baking sheet with parchment paper method, the oven was at 500 degrees (the highest mine will go) and it melted the wax paper and stuck to the naan. Also the naan burned at its thinest most stretched out parts – so maybe I wouldn’t stretch it so thin next time? I don’t know. I had better luck making a non-vegan naan recipe, but I would really like to make this recipe right. To start, I think I’ll try not using any parchment paper next time.

Dear Eva,
First time trying to make naan and I’m so lucky to chanced ipon your recipe. It worked beautifully! I don’t have an oven so I pan fry it and the result is crispy on the outside and fluffy in the inside! Its so Super delicious! I’ll definitely make it again and again! Even thinking of using it as a pizza base (but pan fried style) ? Thank you, Eva!
Cheers!
Lynda
For some reason the dough didn’t rise, I followed the instructions properly. Any chance the yeast is supposed to be out in water and added to wet ingredients instead?

Hello Eva,
Can this Naan be made with any gluten free flour? Chickpea flour? 
Best regards,
Paige

I’m about to try this with sweetened almond milk yogurt….only because it’s all i have and I think a critical part of richner naan. I am noticing sugar is added in recipe anyway, albeit possibly less than what’s in the yogurt I have….I hope this doesn’t result in a sweet naan!
This is an amazing naan recipe, thank you! Non-vegan husband who loves restaurant naan absolutely loved this, and so did I!
This is a flawless recipe! Delicious to the core! Thank you so much!
Correction: What yogurt did you use in your naan?

Hello,
I would love to make your naan.  However, I went from vegetarian to vegan and omitted all dairy.  Do have a replacement for yogurt?
This naan looks amazing, Eva – I’ll have to try my hand at making it! 🙂
Your recipes and photos are just beautiful!

Holy deliciousness, Eva!  This naan is so amazing (as are all your recipes!).  I’ve made it twice now – it’s so easy, pillowy soft in the middle with a beautiful crust on the outside.  My family goes CRAZY for this naan, they gobble every single piece down and there are never any leftovers (much to my chagrin).

Excellent! Made it with organic unsweetened soy milk instead of coconut milk since that’s all I had. Tastes amazing. Had it with your jerk tempeh recipe it’s super easy and tastes great.

The only thing I will do differently is make the batch into more 4 oz. steaks. As a serving for us that should be perfect.  I cut these for serving but they are so tasty we just nibbled on the trimmings, oh well. Thanks for such a versatile recipe!

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Caramel Sauce
comments: Hello Eva, I made this today and it is pure heaven. I’ve made caramel sauce and toffee before but that was when I was a vegetarian and using dairy. So great to be able to make a vegan version. I did make a mistake and used coconut cream from a fridged can of coconut milk 😂. I realised this as it was cooling down. So in fact I made toffee 😁. But I just added some oat milk and it is right as rain. Thank you for your lovely recipe. x

@Rebecca, hello Rebecca, I just made this for the first time. I made sure my butter was really soft. When I added it to the melted sugar mine clumped into toffee but I kept stirring like mad and it finally mixed. Give it another try it’s pure heaven.

Great recipe. 
I’m not normally one to leave comments.
Top tip for cleaning out a caramel pan is to just add water to it and bring to a boil, all the sugar dissolves into the water. No Scrubbing.

This is soooooo good! I used the country crock vegan butter and I think it may have too much water in it because I had a hard time getting it to come together; it did in the end but I think I overcooked it in the process- next time I’ll use earth balance for sure, I was just being cheap because it’s more expensive than the country crock haha. It was still SUPER delicious!! I have used it in lattes and as a dip for apples and honestly sometimes I just eat a spoonful of it when I remember that it is hanging out in the fridge! 🙂

Just made this and it is delicious! I didn’t have any coconut milk on hand, so I used 1/4 regular soy milk and 1/4 room temp earth balance butter. The finished product was a little thick when cooled, but still usable as a dipping sauce. If I made this again I would use the coconut milk just to get the consistency right.
I just tried to make this and the sugar seized immediately when I added the butter 😿

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Berbere Mac and Cheese
comments: This is the best tasting vegan mac and cheese recipe I have ever tried! For the crumb topping I used breadcrumbs and added family favourite vegan cheese https://violifefoods.com/. My kids loved it so much, I will definitely be making this again!
This was really good. My kids and husband loved it.

I just tried this recipe last night for dinner and it turned out to be incredibly  delicious!!! Thank you!
Loved the injera crumbs on top. I dried some leftover injera in the oven (I was going to order Tsiona’s injera crisps – they sound amazing, but they cost $90 to ship to Canada!!)

Thank you so much for introducing me to the injera crisps by Tsiona Foods! They immediately became a favorite snack in my house! I no longer live in a place where I can buy fresh injera at the grocery store and these somewhat fill that craving too!

thecuriouschickpea.title: Easy Vegan Baked Ziti
comments: @Katie, did you end up freezing it with success? Thank you!!
Literally the best vegan meal I’ve ever made or eaten! This is a new family favourite. Thank you for sharing this recipe xx

This recipe turned out absolutely delicious!! In love with that “mozzarella” sauce, so easy and quick to make:)) I didn’t have vegan sausage crumbles on hand so I just used finely chopped cremini mushroom, red bell pepper, broccoli stems along with roughly smashed left over lentils. This will be now my new go to dish for entertaining. Thanks!!

This is the best baked ziti recipe ever! I make this with a roasted red pepper sauce and impossible meat and my non vegan family is obsessed with it! Sometimes I add spinach & mushrooms too, but it’s so good even on its own. I’m making it this week for the maybe 6th time and I’m so excited to have it again!
I baked a half batch of this in the air fryer for 15 minutes and it came out wonderfully! Thank you!

I’ve never made a vegan dish before, let alone one so involved!! Stayed up very late making it and had to improvise a few times, but I had a blast. It turned out beautiful and I hope the recipient enjoys it!! Thanks so much for sharing.
What would you suggest me using instead of the canned whole toms if I don’t have a blender to blend the whole tomatoes?

Hi there, I made this recipe today (looks so good!) and I have a question about the cheese sauce. I used a vitamix with all the ingredients as listed (tapioca flour that was labeled as “also called tapioca starch”), but mine looks a lot thicker than your pics. What did I do wrong? I haven’t baked it yet so I don’t know about the taste.
I used tempeh and seasoned with smoked paprika whilst browninginstead of vegan sausage. Came out great.

I have been making this recipe for a few years now and when I say that it is a fan favorite it absolutely is! My boyfriend and I sometimes make it as often as once a week and it is always my go to when I have meat eaters/non-vegans over and they are always so impressed! The mozzarella sauce is amazing and it thickens up so much in the oven. Absolutely love it and it is no joke one of my favorite recipes!
This is one of my go-to, favorite recipes ever. I use Banza every time and it comes out fantastic!

I really want to make this but I genuinely cannot find refined coconut oil anywhere anymore – I used to rely on it so heavily for baking, but for the last year it seems like everywhere no longer stocks it, which has thrown me for a loop. Has anyone actually has success trying this without coconut oil, or subbed for something else?

This recipe is *amazing*, thank you for sharing! It’s definitely a favorite in my household 🙂 I keep experimenting based on what I have available (type of sausage or tomatoes) – the mozzarella sauce really brings it together. It’s my go-to mozarella sauce now!
Omg!!! Just made this mozzarella cheese sauce and it is soooooo delicious!! You could just pour this over pasta as an Alfredo…haven’t even baked it yet. Will be using this for everything

I didn’t have coconut oil so I substituted with olive oil and it still came out freakin amazing!!! This is one of the best vegan recipes I’ve made yet. My whole family enjoyed it so much. Thank you!!!!!

The mozzarella sauce is amazing. I used my leftover pasta sauce form a vegan lasagna I had made  a couple of days before and some homemade vegan meatballs , so I can’t rate the pasta sauce. I’m sure that if it is anything like the mozzarella it is awesome.  I doubled the recipe and fed 4 non vegan men , plus my self and my husband. They were in heaven and could not believe there was no cheese or meat when I told them. All had. second helping and lucky for me I still had some leftovers. I am now dreaming of vegan meatball sandwiches with that amazing mozzarella sauce.

I LOVE this recipe! It’s been a hit with my non-vegan family (including my Italian grandma)!
I skip the oil in the cheese sauce and I’ve been skipping the sausage. I love using San Marzano tomatoes. I didn’t find it necessary to put them through the food processor, I just break them up a bit with the spatula as they cook.
Last night was my 4th time making it, it was a double batch and everyone got seconds! Thank you!

I’ve made this twice now! I dont normally have coconut oil on hand but I’ve made it substituting once with olive oil and the other time with a vegan butter stick! The butter stick version is out of this world. My boyfriend asked if we could use it as an alfredo sauce next. (And he still eats dairy!) Thank you for this amazing recipe.
I bought regular tapioca pearls and i ground them up in my blender.
Hi!!! I am brand new to your website and i am so glad i found you! I want to make this soon but i. Was wondering if i could use vegetable oil instead of the coconut oil?
I made this tonight. It was surprisingly easy and delicious!
Hi. this looks great.  Would I be able to freeze and reheat to make ahead?

I made a “test run” today and made this in a 3qt dish for my non-vegan family since I’m planning on making it for a friendsgiving tomorrow and they LOVED it. One question though!! I’ve used your recipe to make this twice now and it is unbelievable!  Hard to believe something so easy to make is sooooooooo tasty.  Thanks for sharing the recipe, it’s a firm family favourite and I’m looking forward to serving it at an upcoming dinner party.  Must admit I’ve never had a non-vegan (or even vegetarian) version but can’t believe anything could match this.
It looks fabulous!! I’m making  it for a potluck meal at my church.

Absolutely delicious! My toddler polished off every bowl I gave him for the next few days. It’s rich and decadent and filling. I used Gusta sausages (my fav) and I will make this as a “company’s coming” dish next time. Thank you!

Hi there, I live in the sticks and am poor 😀 so I used this as a base recipe but changed the “mozzarella” sauce a bit – I had neither cashews nor nutritional yeast 🙁 so made a sort of white sauce with some precious vegan grated “cheese” and it is now in the oven, baking and looking pretty promising 🙂 Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!

I am not a cook but reading how easy this recipe is I made it without using my family as guinea pigs. It was delicious, everyone loved it, even meat eaters. I love garlic so I added extra fresh garlic, no powder. I also used soy meatballs instead. Thank you for this recipe. I will now try other recipes.

I used gardein crumbles and a lot more nooch (I can never get enough lol), added some veggies to the sauce. So good! It really is the cashew cheese that makes it totally out of this world. Thank you for sharing this recipe! Such a hit!!

This looks so so so good…..would the recipe work without the oil for the mozzerella?
Yum! I love adding sausage to pasta dishes, I just wish we could buy seitan sausages here! Can’t wait to try it!

thecuriouschickpea.title: Crispy Baked Buffalo Tofu Wings
comments: This is the crispiest tofu recipe I have found so far since becoming vegan over 3 years ago.    My husband works late so instead of tossing the tofu completely in Buffalo sauce and having it get soggy, I just drizzled some over the top of the Buddha bowl I made for dinner.  He can add more later if he wants.   Really great recipe!
Draining tofu should be in the prep time. As should enough time to bread the tofu. Dinner will be an hour late,not that it’s your problem, but this was not easy or quick.
Made these last night for dinner and they are amazing!!!! Took the left overs for lunch today and almost as good. Thank you so much.

I made these tofu wings last night, following the recipe as written, and my boyfriend loved them! I do not like buffalo sauce so I tossed mine in BBQ sauce and put them on a bun – it was an awesome sandwich. Thanks for sharing!
I have been looking forward to making these for weeks. Today, I finally got around to it, and they were absolutely DELICIOUS!!
would this still work using a medium firm tofu if i just press it beforehand for a lot longer?
This is one of my favorite salads! I keep it in our regular rotation and love including it when I have anyone over who “isn’t in to tofu”. They are always pleasantly surprised. Thank you!

Wow these were incredible! Since starting my journey in Januray (now March), I’ve been craving wings so bad and now I have them muhahahaha! I would say after the initial 25 minute bake – follow-up with a 5 minute bake instead of the full 10 to avoid it being overly crispy. Otherwise 10/10 recipe!!!!!

I must have done something slightly wrong. The taste was great and the breaded tofu was super crispy…until I threw them in the mixing bowl and tossed them in the sauce. They became very soggy. Still tasted great and will be good on salad, but not exactly what I was ho[ing for.
These were SO good!!
These are SO GOOD!! I’m a new vegetarian and was really missing buffalo wings- these are a great replacement!
I’ve made these a few times now and it’s one of my favorite recipes! I’m not vegan, but I love that the tofu makes them feel a bit healthier while still keeping the Buffalo taste.
Delicious! Even my daughter, who doesn’t like tofu, liked it. I highly recommend trying it!
Just made these… They are SOOOOOOO good!  Thank you for sharing such a great recipe.

These are the BEST vegetarian wings I have ever had! Franks is my favorite hot sauce and I like to dip with creamy parm dip i buy at a local chain restaurant.  I don’t miss chicken at all.  Thanks for this recipe!  I look forward to trying it with mac & cheese.

I just made these and they were delicious! I did marinate the tofu in some sriracha, cumin, garlic powder & chili powder for a few hours first but otherwise followed the recipe (except I used regular butter) and it turned out amazing!

We absolutely love this recipe! I’ve made it several times. Tonight we made them as recipe suggested and did avocado ones as well. 
Thank you for sharing!

I just made these last night and they are AMAZING! Seriously I ate so many!
I made these for me and my husband the other night. Wow! What a winning recipe! I will he making these again for sure (maybe often;). Thank you for that recipe!
This was delicious. Only thing I’ll change next time is to serve the sauce on the side. I enjoyed eating them straight from the oven!
This recipe is just the best. You can change up the seasonings and hot sauces and it’s still fantastic.  Can’t stop sharing it with my friends.
I have never posted a review on a recipe before but this was great!! Will for sure make again. Thank you!

These were a huge hit! We will definitely be using this recipe again. Lots of flavor + good texture. Other buffalo tofu recipes we’ve tried have been really dull inside but this was not lacking at all.  Thanks for sharing!
I didn’t have any breadcrumbs so I used oats and put them in a food processor. Weren’t crispy but I still loved it!!!!

Made these tonight and they were lovely! Used regular bread crumbs, maybe not *as* crispy but still delicious! Made them in my toaster over and broiled them to crisp them up more. Dipped them in a quick home made tzatziki. I’ll definitely be making them again!
Thanks Eva, can’t wait to check out more of your recipes (:
I have made these over four times. They are amazing. I’m newly vegan. This recipe has  saved me. Thanks

Just tried these vegan tofu bites. They are absolutely delicious. Ever since giving up meat buffalo chicken was one of the things that I really missed… These definitely do it for me. I made these for my husband’s birthday along with some vegan mac & cheese for a southern style birthday dinner. Definitely super excited for these. They will definitely be becoming part of our regular meal lineup yet. Thank you so much for this recipe

I was so impressed with this recipe! It tasted so good and the texture was great. I will definitely be making these again though and was still so pleased with how they turned out 🙂

Made exactly as directed – it was absolutely delicious!  We are definitely making this again.
Definitely a late reply, but we’ve used convection bake on our air fryer to dramatically cut the cooking time on these – something like 8 minutes with no flip required.

Do you think this same recipe could be used for cauliflower?or  tempeh? One of our favorite places does tempeh wings and they’re so nice and crispy (obviously fried!) but we’d love to try a healthier version.

This was amazing! I made a batch and then made more later in the week it was just so good. We ate it as a salad with blue cheese- which I have never liked before. It was very good with this. I just used the franks buffalo sauce as the sauce for the tofu and it was delicious and easy. I think the base recipe of the tofu sticks would be great with other sauces too- a lemon-y sauce to make a vegan lemon chicken.

I don’t know what I did wrong!! I was so excited to eat these and they ended up just tasting like cornstarch. I used regular breadcrumbs instead of panko, but don’t think that should make too much of a difference. ???

These exceeded my expectations. Buffalo wings are my number 1 craving, and these were fantastic. I served them in wraps with lettuce, tomato, cucumber, and avocado. A creamy dressing would pair beautifully. As a vegan buffalo wing recipe 10/10 would recommend. Can’t wait to try the recipe with other sauces, too. Thank you!

I am so impressed with this recipe! I made it using Frank’s new Buffalo Wings sauce. I forgot the 2 Tbsp. olive oil in the panko mixture but the tofu still turned out crispy and delicious. I did have to flip the wings about 15 minutes in to avoid browning them too much, but that could be a result of the lack of oil. They turned out very spicy and fantastic with light ranch dressing.
Thank you so much!
These were soooo gooood – thank you!

Just made this recipe and absolutely *loved* it. My husband isn’t keen on tofu, but I think I’ve got him hooked on this recipe. We absolutely adored the base tofu recipe without the sauce. The sauce nearly killed my hubby’s sensitive taste buds, so I had to tame it a bit. I will definitely be making this again though.

I’ve been eyeing this recipe for a while now and am dying to make a salad w/ it, as pictured! Just curious what other veggies would go well w/ it? And if kale can be used instead of romaine?
Thanks so much!

I made these tofu wings last night for dinner with some sweet potato chips a salad, and OMG they were so delicious. I used encona hot pepper sauce instead because thats what we had in the cupboard. I will definitely be making the again, everyone loved them!
Thanks for sharing! Do they keep long?

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Bacon Mac and Cheese
comments: Thank you for this recipe! It tastes so similar to Upton’s bacon mac ! I would suggest using 2 packages of Upton’s bacon though. And I would suggest mixing the mac noodles and sauce in a separate pan, reserve some of the sauce. Cook the bacon til pretty crisp, then remove from the pan. In a nice cast iron pan, heat up a bit of oil, then add a few servings of mac and cheese, a thin layer. Let it toast, turn once, and then add plenty of the bacon right at the end so it’s still crispy. At Upton’s, their mac is more dry, so I that’s why I’ll reserve some of the sauce next time. A bit more dry to get that crisp on it. Maybe some toasted breadcrumbs to finish it? It was absolutely delish. So happy that you were able to capture the strong cheesy flavor in that sauce! Can’t wait to re-crisp the leftovers tomorrow, maybe I’ll grab some more bacon and add that too! Thanks again, very enjoyable, and saved me a trip to the city!

As to the origin of shakshouka شكشوكه it is north african countries of Libya and Tunisia. The word shakshouka is Tunisian arabic for “mixture”. It traditionaly served in a cast iron skillet or a tajine as in morocco. It is the quintessential meal of Arabic cuisine. Thank you

thecuriouschickpea.title: Restaurant Style Chana Masala
comments: I have made a fair bit of Chana Masala in the past 10 years but this one is our favorite. It is SO excellent. So easy to make. Hard to believe but its even better the second day.

This was my first homemade Indian dish. After I found all the ingredients – I live near a big Indian neighborhood – I was surprised at how simple the recipe was to prepare. I don’t have anything to compare it with, since I’ve never tried it anywhere, but this was delicious! Looking at other recipes, and from what I’ve probably seen on Indian restaurant buffets, Chana Masala looks soupy. I’m glad this one wasn’t, but I had to stir it frequently to keep it from sticking. I used dried garbanzos, soaked overnight and cooked, added a couple extra red chili peppers, and served it with brown basmati rice. I will be making this often, since I now have a lifetime supply of Indian spices. Thank you for sharing this recipe!

My family’s Christmas Eve tradition is to gather with our Jewish friends for Indian food. So this year, I made Eva’s chana masala, biryani, raita, and mango lassi for a feast at home. These are, by far, absolutely the most delicious Indian recipes I’ve ever made – and I’ve made recipes from many sources. I’ve finally found my go-to chana masala recipe now – no need for all the others I’ve tried over the years! Thank you, Eva – I will come back to your recipes again and again!

I will definitely try that next time I make this, cuz I definitely want to try again!
Oh also, even though I struggled to get the gnocchi to stay in shape, they held together just fine when cooking. The end result was super sticky because of all the oil I used, so I laid them out to dry a bit on a sheet of parchment paper so that they didn’t all glob together.

thecuriouschickpea.title: Homemade Vegan Wontons
comments: Nice recipe but i wanted to mention that your “classic” wonton shape, while perfectly functional, is not the real wonton shape. For real chinese wontons you place teaspoon of filling just above one corner of wrapper, fold corner over filling, roll to tuck point under. Moisten two side corners and pull them together behind filled corner and overlap slightly, pinch together to seal. This leaves a nice floaty little tail. Takes a little practice but just as easy once you get the hang of it. Of course you can also just pinch corner to corner for a triangle shape before sticking ends together or stick with the rectangle shape like youve done. In the end the only things that really matter are that they taste delicious and are cruelty free!

So amazing! We had some leftover wonton wrappers and needed to use them up, and since then they’ve been a staple. We added maybe 5x the amount of scallions because we’re fiends for the stuff. We pan fried then steamed for the crunch and chew and OMG.

comments:
@thecuriouschickpea, 
Freezing dough happens after the final proofing. When you thaw it out it will be ready to shape and use.

@Tony, 
Unless you are using a brick yeast, rapid rise is perfectly fine. The difference is you just do not need to proof it first.

@Eva Agha, I believe the only difference between instant and active yeast is that instant yeast has smaller granules with some yeast activator. This allows you to add it directly to the dough. If you follow the directions on your active yeast (add to water and wait) then you should get the same result as if you had used instant yeast.

Oh man, this recipe was a total dud for me! I’m posting in hopes anyone has some advice.
I have been making a lot of homemade pizza since March and they have all turned out amazing but this is the first overnight dough i have made and it was awful, so if anyone who hasnt tried making this yet is reading it, please beware. 
This recipe seemed doomed from the start, are the water and flour ratios correct? When I put in 1.5cups water and FOUR cups of flour it was just a hard lumpy mass. Literally unkneadable, and looked nothing like the nice wet slack dough in the video. I triple read the instructions after to make sure I didn’t misread anything but alas, that is in fact the ratio. Just to get the dough to a kneadable state, i had to basically double the water amount. I had a feeling from this time that it was in trouble but i still followed all the instructions and wait times just in case a miracle happened (it did not).
After the overnight rise, when i took the dough ball out it wasnt a cohesive dough, you could clearly separate the dough from where i folded it onto itself from the day before (again, i think the dough was too dry despite my extra water). After priming my oven, i stretch the dough, topped it, and baked.
The pizza was edible, but the dough was just so dense and hard and didnt rise very much at all. I may try and make it again just to see but I also dont want to waste ingredients. 
I did double check my measurements and this has never been a problem for me with any of the other multiple recipes i have used.

@Phil, 2 cups is about 400 grams

It’s a common opinion found everywhere when people talk about chillies that it’s the seeds which are hot and if you don’t want your food to be so hot you should remove the seeds. this is not in fact the case. The seeds do not contain casaicin, the hot ingredient of chillies, and removing them or leaving them will not affect the heat. The active ingredient comes from the pith and ribs of the chili.
@Juanita Franklin,  it doesn’t matter what kind of chili peppers you use just use whichever ones you’ve got

@Eva Agha, the thing to do is reduce the water if you want to, by simmering the lentils. Just keep them on a low heat and make sure they don’t burn or stick to the bottom of the pan and you can reduce the water to the consistency that you want

@Carolyn Hughes,
Cups are a really bad, inaccurate way of measuring amounts. It’s perfectly simply, and far more accurate, to use proper measurements such as grams
@Beth, yes that’s way too much water
@Phil, yeah they really shouldn’t be using cups. It’s an absurd measurement even in American professional cooks use measured amounts (usually grams) but it’s ready to find conversions on the net
@Phil, I would do what Melissa did, I made it with 8 cups and it was waaaaaaaaaaaay too much water.

@Phil, hey Phil here is a REALLY simple way to use American measurements! On your measuring jug you’ll see the 8 oz mark that is 1 cup. It doesn’t matter if the thing you are measuring is dry or wet. A cup is a cup. If you need a cup of water fill to 8 oz mark if you need. Cup of flour or lentils or whatever fill to the 8 oz mark! It’s seriously that simple. DON’T bother with trying to figure out the weight etc. I used to use an 8 oz mug and just scoop stuff with that until o got “real” measuring cups. I hope this helps.
1 cup= 8 oz mark
1/2 cup= 4 oz mark
1/4 cup= 2 oz mark

@Phil, I ran into the exact same problem! I wish I had read your post first. Mine came out more like lentil soup and the spices were thin out way too much. The flavor is great, just not “concentrated” enough. I will do the recipe again, but with much, much less water.

I can’t understand why you would be disappointed if you made it correctly, but using a little common sense works wonders.  Cooking involves ‘tasting’ every so often and should always be an adventure.  It sounds like you are beginning to branch out of your comfort zone, because if you were an experienced cook, you would have known to tweak it.
     If you ARE a beginner, then count this as a learning process and figure out what went wrong.  I made this and it was incredible!  Just because a recipe is ‘out there’ doesn’t mean it’s going to be perfect for every one, every time.. be nice, work it out and add something constructive as a comment next time!

Might just add a cup less water next time as the consistency may have been a bit too runny for my liking! 
Otherwise, utterly GORGEOUS.
Thanks so much! I did add water and it worked. Just a gorgeous recipe. My family loved it as well – first time eating dal for my kids. I’m going to try many more recipes from your site.
Eva, hello! This recipe tastes fabulous. However, it does not have enough liquid. I think I was not supposed to drain the lentils, which I did.  Can I add water to fix?

This is my go to dahl recipe! I use half the amount of lentils and 3 1/2 cups water, also adding turmeric and garam masala. I use more than half of the spices (although under half tbsp curry powder due to added spices) as I enjoy the stronger flavour. I also blend some of the onion/spice/tomato mixture for a smoother dahl. Thanks for the recipe!
Hi Eva. I have been looking for a tasty dhal recipe for a while. What better place to start than from a namesake. I will let you know how I get on.

I, too, was worried about the amount of water listed. I did cook the lentils in the full 8 cups listed but then I drained most of it – probably 6 cups – off. I like a thicker dal  and figured I could add it back in slowly if I needed to. This worked perfectly for me and the flavors only get better as it sits. Thanks !

Great recipe thanks!  My first time making Dal.  I could only find green lentils and they didn’t cook down much so I blended half of them for a more soup texture.  The tadka was so good and aromatic I almost hated to add anything to it.  I will definitely be making this again and look forward to making it with red lentils next time.
Winter in Cape Town pairs perfectly with this delicious authentic Dal!! So glad I found your recipe. Had all the ingredients and followed your method to the T! Thanks for sharing ?
May I know how long can you keep the cooked dal in the fridge? Thanks!

You know, I loved the commentary as I am a learner in the field of Dal. I super appreciated the whys and wherefores. I failed last night with yellow split peas which were still crunchy after 3 hours of cooking so was looking for a red lentil recipe. I’ll also cook the lentils separately in future before adding to the good stuff. This is pretty standard format, V. Most of us know that the recipe is to be found at the bottom.  So don’t hesitate to use your thumbs next time.
I’ve had trouble finding red lentils anywhere because of the pandemic. Would green lentils work fine for this recipe? What would I have to tweak?
Can you replace the curry powder with anything else? Or leave it out altogether?
If you have a stick blender, use that for the entire lot of dal after tadka!!!
When you say “curry powder” what specifically do you mean? What type of curry powder? Garam masala?
Lovely, nuanced reply to a very rude person…one who probably didn’t deserve your kindness. And delicious recipe, too. Thank you.

I haven’t tried this recipe yet (planning on doing so tonight) so I can’t really evaluate whether it’s too much water or not. It sounds like it’s a lot of water though, and I’ll probably start with 6 cups and add more if it’s too thick.
Anyway, I always translate 1 cup to 2½ dl for simplicity, meaning 2 cups are 5 dl (or a half litre) and 8 cups are 2 litres.
Made this for the first time today. Thank you so much for posting this recipe. It’s was absolutely delicious. And to top it of we had a lovely chai tea made with condensed milk afterwards.
Drain off the extra liquid and reserve it. Then you can add it back in to the desired consistency.

Awesome!

1.  Added a vegetable stock cube to the lentils.

This was wonderful and posted at the perfect time! I had some wilting kale and tomato paste left over in the fridge and this was a DELICIOUS way to use them up!!

Hello! This looks very good, and I’m looking forward to trying it! Could I substitute something  else for coconut milk in the  the red pepper sauce?

Just made this last night and it is absolutelt divine!!!! Even better the next day. Turned out great! I had cooked farro on hand so i used that as the grain. Didn’t need to use the breadcrumbs but did need a tad more olive oil to give the mix more moisture. Used fresh basil in the sauce and served it all over zoodles. Was a big hit with the hubby, will definitely make it again!

I followed the recipe exactly as written, only I substituted walnuts for pecans. I didn’t need to use the breadcrumbs either as they bound together just fine without. They turned out perfect! Great recipe, love the sauce as well!
Some recipes just make me stop in awe at how wonderful they look, this is definitely one of them!

This was fun…I just glanced through the recipe last night and today Made it from memory with a bunch of changes of course LOL.I toasted the pecans, I sauteed some onion celery and mushroom all finally minced and added that, rough chopped pecans the chickpeas separately from the well cooked brown rice and hand mixed / massaging the ingredients together using your seasonings plus some lemon juice, coconut aminos AND tamari, poultry seasonings… I plan to make the roasted pepper coconut cream sauce tomorrow and going to add some Garam Masala. Thanks for the inspiration,1 needs to have a feel for this kind of cooking, squishing the ingredients by hand works better and of course using short -grain brown rice yields better results! IMO…
Has anyone made this grain free? What did you use?

These were absolutely delicious!! Will definitely be making this again, especially because it’s easy to swap ingredients based on what you have. I did a quinoa + millet grain mixture instead of brown rice, and then walnuts + pumpkin seeds instead of pecans (just because I didn’t have what the recipe was calling for). Was just so, so good!

The “meatballs” and sauce were really good. They were not mushy at all like others have said. They will be added to the rotation. I did make some changes like some others have mentioned: cashews instead of pecans due to allergies and went for a Indian/curry taste instead of Italian so changed the seasoning.

Hi Eva,

Great recipe tried it for a dinner. It came out really good. Will definitely do this one again. Have you ever tried freezing them? I would love to have these ready to go on a busy night.

It’s a disaster i made the balls And put in the fridge but when i put them in the oven they fell apart, i put them in the compost and had a cup of tea and a piece of fruit for dinner

Has anyone tried this recipe substituting the nuts with something else for tree but allergies??? I really want to make this for my grandson

I really loved this recipe! Decided to comment here because I did see some people were quite unhappy with the recipe. Some people were saying the balls felt apart when in the sauce. It didn’t happen to me – the balls were quite solid and I even left one of them still soaking in the sauce in the fridge for the night (just to test) and it was pretty solid in the morning. What might have helped in my case is that I intentionally overcooked rice and made it just a tiny bit slushy and so the rice helped chickpeas to bind well. Try it.
The sauce was great too! I added some turmeric for the color because my peppers were rather white.
The most important thing is that my meat loving husband loved the chickpeas balls! I always warn him when I make something vegan and ask him to tell the truth if he doesn’t like it.  I warned him this time too but he really loved them and even asked for the leftovers to be packed for lunch. It was quite unfortunate because I was going to finish them myself the next day lol.

I wish I had paid Emily Su’s review more attention, because I do agree largely with what she said. While it did gel up almost perfectly (the alcoholic ones, anyway; I also made some virgin versions and they did not gel nearly as well), there was something very off about the texture of the ginger cream layer. I considered mango nectar but chose the cocktail juice instead mostly because it was cheaper, so maybe it would have tasted better with the mango nectar. I dunno.

I made this sauce tonight with some thick spaghetti and hot Italian beyond meat sausage. When you’re really craving that classic spaghetti dinner, this totally hits the spot, and you don’t notice the spinach (well… My toddler did). I made this pretty mild for my toddler, and she gobbled it up. My husband and I just sprinkled a little extra red pepper on top. The sauce recipe is pretty simple, but that really lets the tomatoes shine. It’s subtly sweet with great garlic and basil flavor. Way better than jar sauce! Plus, easy to build off of for different flavors or a more complex sauce!

thecuriouschickpea.title: Sindhi Vegetable Biryani
comments: My family’s Christmas Eve tradition is to gather with our Jewish friends for Indian food. So this year, I made Eva’s biryani, chana masala, raita, and mango lassi for a feast at home. The biryani, in particular, is incredible – better than what we’ve had at many restaurants! It requires a few steps but it is so worth it for a special meal (and lots of leftovers – the best!) thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Buffalo Wing Mac and Cheese
comments: I LOVE this recipe! I started making it back in 2018 or 2019 and it’s always my go-to when I need some comfort food! The Mac n cheese has such a good flavor, is creamy & doesn’t have that off vegan flavor/texture that some nut-based mac’s can have. Thank you!

@Eva Agha, You emailed me the recipe a year ago, thank you for that and I see that it’s visible again on the website, too.  I finally got around to making it today and wow, I wish I had made it earlier!  I’ve made the buffalo tofu a few times for salads, and it is soo so good, but this is the first time trying the mac n cheese. I didn’t like the first couple of bites, maybe because I was expecting a cheese flavor and nothing but cheese tastes like cheese, lol (I’m not vegan, can you tell?), but once we changed the name to mac n sauce and just appreciated it for what it was, we realized it was incredibly delicious.  I went back for seconds!  I often crave mac n cheese, but dairy doesn’t sit well in my body, but this made me feel great!  And so quick and easy to make!  It is going into my recipe book for sure!  I love that it is a healthy plus animal friendly comfort food!  Yum!  Thanks!  Going to browse all your other recipes now for more gem, hehee!
This was so good, wholefamily loved it!
Made this tonight!! Wonderful. Thank you for the recipe

This is so delicious and easy! I love the the ingredients for the Mac n cheese sauce are non perishable and can whip up in just a few minutes!  Thank you so much for sharing! Can’t wait to enjoy this again!
Same, right now I can only see the comments, there is not recipe visible on the page for me… :/
Dang, just started pressing the tofu and…the recipe is gone??? Just comments now.

I’ve been sitting on this recipe for a while and am so glad I finally tried it tonight! The buffalo tofu is amazing! I’ll be using this breading/baking method in other recipes too, it’s so good. And the mac & cheese is the first vegan one I’ve made that I’ll actually make again, just as others have said. The texture is perfect, and although I don’t love that I can taste some coconut, that is easily masked with a little extra buffalo sauce ? Do you think I could skip the coconut milk next time and sub more plant milk instead, or does it need the coconut milk to thicken? Thanks for the great recipe! Shared with some vegan Facebook groups ?

The buffalo part of this recipe is amazing. 100% will make that again. The cheeze sauce, unfortunately, wasn’t our taste. The texture was slimy, not creamy. Sadly we had a few bites and had to toss it.  I have had much better success with cashew based cheeze sauces. Cheers.
Can this be made in advance and reheated?

Okay I am a meat-eater but I did used to be vegetarian. I had tried several mac n “cheese” recipes with pumpkin and/or cashew and the like but was never a fan. Now I still entertain some vegan friends and decided to give this one a go. Well let me tell you, I’ve never even made a from-scratch real mac n cheese recipe that I’ve liked as much as this one! I am not a huge smoke fan so I did use only one teaspoon of smoked paprika but this was so silky, creamy, and flavorful. It is a perfect accomplice to a backyard BBQ. The tofu was superb too. All in all, a huge hit with everyone! My only complaint is when I added the tapioca starch it thickened almost instantly and I had to whisk very fast and add water due to clumps. End result was still fantastic though! I only had about 10 oz of pasta but added all of the sauce to it anyways. There wasn’t a drop left.
This recipe is fantastic!  Best vegan cheese sauce I’ve ever made and the tofu was crispy and delicious and perfect! Will definitely be making again soon!
This mac and cheese was a huge hit here!. My son LOVED it! Thanks for the recipe.

Dude.  This whole recipe is delicious, but you just made my day with this cheese sauce!  I’ve tried what feels like a billion (but is probably only about a dozen) recipes for cheese sauce, and this was the first one where I was like, Eureka!  We’ve got it!!  *so good*!!!  It’s the closest to a real mac and cheese sauce that I’ve come across in the vegan world, and I could just hug you.   🙂

Mmmmm this was so, so good! I  would not have thought that mac and cheese could taste like this with coconut milk, wow.  I followed pretty much exactly but we were low on plant milk so I just filled the empty coconut milk can with some of the pasta cooking water and splashed that in instead. Worked great. Delicious with loads of freshly ground black pepper. We also loved sprinkling the top with the little bits of spicy Panko that were left at the bottom of the bowl after tossing the tofu wings in the hot sauce. Thank you!

I tried only the coconut milk mac & cheese part of this recipe last night, just to test it out.  It was absolutely fantastic!  My teenage boys took second helpings,which, of course, is the true measure of success!  I have tried nut based mac & cheese recipes that I thought were okay, but none of them really “wowed” me – yours totally does!  I will definitely make the entire recipe next time but now I know that your recipe is absolutely going to be my “go to” recipe for macaroni and cheese!  Thank you!
This looks om nom nom amazing, thank you for  sharing. I’m happy that you chose to use tofu for the wings rather than cauliflower.
This recipe looks amazing! The creamy mac and cheese with the crunchy tofu wings plus that hit of spice…. I can’t wait to make (and EAT) this!

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Raita: Indian Cucumber and Mint Yogurt Sauce
comments: Shut Up! I’m Gujarati! And it was definitely unpasteurized milk from  a buffalo, pasteurized came from the ‘dayree’ in bags. I never connected the word ‘dairy’ when I was a kid but now it makes sense. My mom still makes homemade yogurt in N.Y. because it’s never as good as Indian Homemade  Dahi. I thought when I went Vegan, cheese would be my biggest hurdle. But its YOGURT! And Raitya! I use a mix of ground coriander and ground cumin which is the only difference. Ive also made it with coleslaw or just the addition of some finely shredded purple cabbage to cucumber. This is my weakness. I have yet to find a decent vegan yogurt that’s plain w/o breaking the bank. 2 cups for $8 and to toss it after my first taste makes me feel awful.

comments: The curry powder recipe isn’t good at all. Tastes of turmeric and not much else.

Authentic Jamaican style black eye peas is not made with curry. Trinidadians use curry. Our black eye peas is cooked the way it is coked in West Africa e.g Ghana. I think you might want to call this something else!
I can’t see using canned peas in such a beautiful dish.

This was delicious! I had access to fresh zipper cream peas, so I used that instead of canned peas and omitted the hot peppers because I’m a wimp. I love the flavors from the curry powder, lime, and coconut milk!

My mother is from the Bahamas, so of course I grew up with those yummy flavors and this hit the SPOT!! Tasted like home! I added about 3-4 bay leaves and a good shake of whole all spice once I added the water! I also added a little scotch bonnet pepper sauce because I didn’t have a whole scotch bonnet pepper and didn’t want to substitute that flavor with a different one!! Simply fabulous!

I love this recipe I added pinto beans and chick pea as well as black bean for more variety and had it with basmati rice and paratha. A really tasty meal and a truly authentic curry goat dinner without the goat!

this sounds delicious!  But I do not use oil.  How do you think this recipe can be adapted without oil?

I made this and will make again, but with a few revisions. I feel it has unnecessary steps that make it more complicated (and use more dishes) than it needs to. There was too much soy sauce and not enough orange juice, it needs more than 1/2 a cup. I used at least a cup of OJ. The cornstarch and soy sauce doesn’t need to be added separately to the broccoli, in fact I’d skip adding anything to the broccoli to keep the dish lighter and less salty. Next time I make this I will make the orange sauce (more OJ), sear the seitan with the cornstarch for the crispiness, lightly steam or microwave the broccoli, then throw everything together with the sauce.
Love how quick and easy this is! And the addition of orange – can just imagine how good it taste! Xo

Hi Sarah-Eve
I grew up in Nepal enjoying various styles of momos (Newari, Tibetan, round ones and crescent-shaped, etc). When I’ve made chutney (or “achar” as we call it in Nepali), the seams is dry roasted separately, then blended until it’s almost a paste and then added to the chutney preparation. It was SO good and reminded me of when I used to get dairy fondues out at nice restaurants. I will definitely be making it again and again. Thank you so much!! 🙂

Hey Eva-first of all, I love your recipes and am so grateful for them. I’ve spent some time in India as my partner is from Delhi, so to be able to find better-than-restaurant indian food that is also vegan is incredible (especially because his family doesn’t believe indian food can be made without ghee or other animal products, as you probably suspect). So thank you. It’s so inspiring to the two of us as vegans.
On to my question, which might be a bit silly: how do I know if the cheese is culturing? Will it taste very different, or just a little different? I’ve been culturing it in LA here for about 27 hours with the windows open about half the time (temps in the 70s & 80s) and don’t notice a big difference in taste, if any at all. It’s definitely yummy, but I’m not sure if it’s culturing.
Any help is appreciated because I’ll definitely be culturing lots of vegan cheeses from now on. 🙂

Susana

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Hazelnut Cake with Whipped Chocolate Ganache
comments:
I rarely comment, but I had to for this one! I scaled the 8″ recipe up 1.7X and baked it in a 12-cup bundt pan. Topped with a dark chocolate ganache and roasted hazelnut meal, this cake was a dream: super moist, hazelnutty and all around delicious!
First, thanks for publishing weights for your recipes. It makes scaling up and down super easy. Secondly, thanks for this wonderful recipe itself!

I planned to make my hazelnut meringue tower for Christmas but something went wrong so I had to improvise. I wanted a cake with hazelnuts and when I saw you had a recipe I went for it! I was very confident it would be awesome, because I made your vanille layer cake a while back and it was amazing as well.
I filled it with a chocolate mousse and used a hazelnut buttercream as a topping. All vegan of course. I made two 8″ cakes. Next time I will cut off the domes as the cake layers were a bit too high.
Thanks for another great recipe!
Hi, I’m planning on using this recipe to make cupcakes but I’m not sure which measurement to use (6 inch or 8 inch). Which measurement do you think will give 12 cupcakes?

how much almond extract and vanilla would you recommend to turn this into an almond flavored cake? thanks for sharing!

Thank you for the tip! Following your advice, I ended up replacing the coconut milk with about 200g of Ripple half and half, which is the thickest plant based creamer I can find out there that has a fairly neutral taste. I think it worked out quite nicely! I let it sit in the fridge for about 5 hours before whipping it, so it was a tad runny half way through frosting the cake. I think it probably would be fine if I let it set in the fridge overnight. Overall, I think the ganache turned out really well! This recipe is most definitely a keeper! Thank you again!

Can coconut milk be substituted? I’m concerned that the frosting will taste a little too coconuty. By the way your cake recipe is AMAZING!!!!!!! I tried your vanilla cake recipe and this is literally THE best vegan cake recipe period. I can’t wait to try the chocolate cake one!
Thanks so much! ?

The yellow cake is delicious and the ganache is sooo rich and yummy! thecuriouschickpea.title: Sticky Teriyaki Tofu and Cauliflower with Silan
comments: The batter was very watery and didn’t stick to the cauliflower or the tofu, so nothing was crispy. The flavour was nice, but considering it didn’t work as planned, it wasn’t worth the effort.
Good flavors but way too salty, and I love salt!   I would cut the tamari/soy sauce in half at the very least.

This tastes fine, but it’s a boatload of work and makes a ton of dishes with two different bowls for coating the cauliflower and tofu, then baking, and finally transferring to a wok. It’s fine, but it’s not worth the time and dishes created. I made rice flour, in my Blendtec but I think you could use regular flour if you don’t have it.
This is no dish to attempt on a weeknight (glad I didn’t).

thecuriouschickpea.title: Easy Vegan Pie Dough
comments: Hi Eva, thanks for the outstanding recipe! I even didn’t have time to do the slow, blind baking method that you referred to by Stella Parks. I actually made the dough just like you instructed but then I quickly rolled it out and refrigerated it for 1.5 hours (all I had time for!). I had to blind bake it at 400 for 20 minutes instead of 350 for an hour. It still turned out really delicious! I used Miyoko’s salted stick butter. This will be my go to quiche dough recipe from now on but next time I’ll do it just like you said!

25g Apple Cider Vinegar
675g Plant Milk
525g All-Purpose Flour
425g Sugar
15g Baking Powder
5g Baking Soda
12.5g Salt
205g Oil
40g Vanilla

I’m experienced in making vegan/eggless cupcakes, but have only dabbled in eggless layer cakes. A friend asked me to make a birthday cake for her egg-allergic son, so I tested several recipes and this was by far the best. The texture was moist and tender, not gummy as some eggless cakes can be. The cake wasn’t overly sweet, with a delicious aroma. I used cow’s milk instead of plant-based, since full vegan was not a requirement, and the cake turned out fantastic. I will definitely use again!

thecuriouschickpea.title: The Best Vegan Spinach Artichoke Dip
comments: THIS. This dip is awesome. And I’m not talking awesome for being a healthy food or awesome for a vegetable dip or awesome for a homemade version of a restaurant appetizer staple. It is just plain awesome. I was skeptical of the whole tofu and nutritional yeast thing, but it works and boy, does it work well. I’m not vegan or even vegetarian,  but I am always on the hunt for healthier versions or things. I would gladly choose this dip over any other. No matter your diet (or lack of diet), I highly recommend this dip. You could easily trick somebody into thinking this thing is 1000 calories per fork full.

This is seriously so good, I made it for Christmas Eve and already we are making another batch on Boxing Day because it is just that tasty! I’ve tried so many vegan, nut  free spinach/artichoke dips and they never turn out well but this one was unreal. Served for the whole family and everyone enjoyed it!

So good. I tried for 2 weeks to get chives at several places but they weren’t available anywhere so I ended up using dried. Also didn’t have the thyme or oregano, so I ended up subbing some other spices. I’m sure it would have been super amazing with the correct spices. I’m rating it now with a bit of baguette, and don’t feel like that paired well. I have a lot left so I’ll try with some other stuff. Also I used vegan Parmesan instead of nutritional yeast.
my boyfriend is vegan so I made this dip for him and we were in HEAVENNNN. thank you so much for posting this. I’m going to be using this recipe many more times xxx
Wow this dip looks incredible!! I’ve always loved spinach and artichoke dip at parties 🙂

I used the vegan liquid mozzarella so I had to drop the temp to 525 so it wouldn’t burn but it was still perfect. Best pizza I’ve had since going vegan. The pizza gods and my tummy thank you so much for this!

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Aquafaba Strawberry Italian Meringue Buttercream
comments: This is such a good recipe!!! Thank you so much! I love baking and despite being vegan for 5 years now, at the beginning I didn’t know how to bake vegan, so I just baked for the others and felt bad for the animals, because its a bit ironic for me being vegan but then serving others animal products. The first time I made it was for my workplace and everyone loved it (it looked great, too!). Then I made it a few of times for family, etc. And everyone absolutely loved it. Most people doubt that a vegan cake can taste good before they taste it but once they do, they cannot stop eating it. Thank you so much!

Thanks for the amazing recipe! I did it without the strawberries (as per your easy vanilla cake) and I found it perfect as buttercream to cover a 3 layer cake. It was very soft at the beginning, but after some minutes in the fridge it was perfect to frost and cover the cake. However, I put it overnight in the fridge and its consistency got too hard (even after having left it long out of the fridge before tasting it). I will definitely keep it as a buttercream recipe, but do you have any other suggestion for a softer frosting that would work OK for a 3 layer cake? I need to prepare my sister’s wedding cake and I’ve been trying several recipes but with no success. She would like a vegan 2 tier cake (3 layer each tier).
To be honest, I had the same frosting journey and I hear you 100%! Can’t wait to try this recipe today, thank you for all the love and care you put into your postings!
(it’s worth noting as well, that I am following the suggestion from your vegan vanilla cake recipe to omit the strawberry sauce)

Hi, I just made this recipe on a trial run for using it to make a birthday cake for my vegan friend. The general consensus among the people who tried it is that its very greasy, and sort of just tastes like crisco, and it was very runny. I wanted to confirm I understood the recipe, it calls for 24oz fat total: 16oz vegan shortening (crisco in my case) and 8oz vegan butter (sunflower butter in my case). Have you run into either of those issues, and do you have any recommendations for fixing them if you have? Thanks so much! Even with the issues I had with the frosting the cake as a whole was a big hit
Can you freeze this recipe? And then thaw and ice the cake at a later time?

I’m no genius baker; I make everything by following recipes. I’ve had success with making baked goods, but  this is the best cake I have ever made, and the easiest. I couldn’t find chocolate extract locally nor could I procure it online in time (the linked chocolate extract in the recipe is no longer available), but I was able to get Droste cocoa and the cake was fabulously, exotically chocolatey. This recipe yielded enough batter for two 6″ layers. I lacked the bandwidth and thermometer for the Italian meringue, so I made American strawberry vegan buttercream frosting and decorated with sliced strawberries and chopped walnuts. Fellow amateurs, be not afraid. You got this. Divine.

I was impressed with this recipe because even though it was a bit complicated, it turned out perfectly the first time and I’m a novice baker. It’s very helpful to have each step laid out so explicitly. Without the strawberry, I have to say the frosting is quite bland. But a gorgeous texture. I used freeze dried strawberries instead of purée and it was delicious. Everyone was impressed how creamy it was. I definitely recommend adding salt if your aquafaba is unsalted.

Hi, We made the meringue buttercream, but cut the recipe down to a fourth, which meant we only used 6oz of shortening.  Everything went well, and the texture is gorgeous, but it tastes like shortening.  It’s a little sweet and strawberryish, but the  overwhelming taste is shortening?  Any ideas what we did wrong?  Thank you!

I made this will Cisco shortening and Pure soya butter. I also burnt the sugar slightly. The texture and sweetness were perfect tho! So I’d like to attempt this recipe again!

Gloria

I used Miyoko’s vegan butter (baking/unsalted kind) because I was out of coconut oil and it works great too, though I do think they didn’t spread as much as they would have with coconut oil. They also didn’t brown very much, but could’ve been my oven. Will try again with coco oil next time!

These were delicious. I didn’t have coconut oil so made them with vegan butter instead and they were still good. I used fewer chocolate chips to make them less sweet and half a teaspoon of salt in the dough. Thanks for the recipe!

@thecuriouschickpea, I just made these also,and baked one sample cookie so far after chilling dough in the fridge for hours and these spread out lots leaving edges burnt and cookie not firm…had to eat it on a plate with a spoon. delicious, but would love to know what I can do to the remaining dough balls ready to be baked tomorrow. much appreciated!

Delicious! I subbed the coconut oil with some leftover pulp from my oat milk to cut down on fat/oil. These are so yummy. thank you for this awesome recipe!

My colleague partner made this and brought them to work and they were so delicious… I asked her for the recipe. I then made them at home and they are hit! Making another batch tonight. Super easy simple to make and my go-to cookies to make when I visit friends and such!

This is such a reliable recipe – I brought them to work and two people have asked for the recipe. What I particularly love is how flexible these cookies are. I’ve made them 3 times now and each time have had to stray slightly because I didn’t have all the correct ingredients, or used slightly different cooking times, or even had to hand-whip the wet ingredients in absence of an electric mixer: on every occasion they’ve still turned out YUM. I’ve also been melting my (stiff) tahini in a pot, which creates a nice smooth consistency and adds a slightly more roasted-nut flavour.
Best cookies ever!  Crispy edges and soft and gooey in the Center. Thank you!

Love the flavor, but mine turned out quite hard and crumbly. Hard to bite into after storing for several days. I’m hoping this was just as simple as baking them too long. Going to try again this weekend and keep a closer eye on the bake time!
Made these today AND I CANNOT STOP EATING THEM!! Followed the recipe to the T and they were perfect.

mine turned out too soft and cakey…

I think this would be amazing on a bagel as is or with more herbs and spices.

This recipe is amazing! I feel like it would be perfect in taquitos, enchiladas or quesadillas but I’m curious if it’s possible to use it in anything that’s going into a hot pan or oven because I imagine the coconut oil would melt into a liquid state. Have you tried using it like that before?

My cheese still in the fridge solidifying but I have just tried the cheese scraped with homemade bread and it tasted pretty good! I made this once before and loved it!  I decided to make it again this morning, but didn’t have any onion powder.  I subbed it with Everything but the Bagel seasoning!  It tastes so good!  I can’t wait to have it tonight.  Thanks for such an awesome recipe.

I discovered this recipe a few weeks ago and fell in love with it immediately.  It has to be one of the tastiest, easy to make dairy free cheese recipes ever. Delicious!!!   I substituted 1 tsp of molasses instead of the 2 tsp of  barley malt syrup and the colour worked perfectly.  I put the molasses into the warm water and added the 2 tsp of yeast and proofed it for about 6 minutes.  After the mixer I kneaded for 6 minutes.  I also used microwave-melted margarine instead of plant milk for brushing the tops of buns and I brushed the leftover margarine several times between uses onto the knife to make the slits. thecuriouschickpea.title: Cajun Soy Curls and Creamy Vegan Jalapeño Grits
comments: This is one of my favorite recipes for polenta.  Very tasty. I would not have thought of using Cajun spices!

This looks great! One suggestion, though – because my south-Louisiana-born self can’t resist! If you want a more authentic Cajun flavor, instead of garlic + scallions for the base, start with a combination of onion + celery + bell pepper, then the garlic and add top with the green part of the scallion when serving. Onion + celery + bell pepper is the “Holy Trinity” of Cajun cuisine. (I hope you don’t mind the suggestion! Thanks for showing a little love to Cajun cooking!)

I love soy curls!  They are not like TVP (made from soy flour) but the whole beans so no processing other than drying.  I have found they taste even better if I soak them in vegan chick’n stock instead of just the water. Just bought the bulk box (12 pounds!) of them to split with my daughter… so we will be eating lots of soy curls for sure.  As long as you keep them in a freezer they last for ages.  Cheapest price I found for the bulk was direct from Butler Foods in case anyone is interested.
This was delicious and satisfying. I cant wait to try different spice combinations.

I’d like to try it with tofu – would you recommend marinating the tofu in the sauce or something similar beforehand?
Thanks!

This was excellent! I left out the chilis (our kids don’t like spice), but it still had good kick with the curry. We’ll be making this again soon!
Thanks!

thecuriouschickpea.title: Savory Crepes with Almond Cheese, Sautéed Spinach and Vegan Hollandaise
comments:
Just a followup.  Next day had more fresh spinach so braised it with carrots, Italian pepper, leeks, etc. in a little white wine.  Then made potato and turnip (1 turnip to 4 potatoes) mash, folding in the remaining cheese.  Well it (the cheese) seemed to have matured overnight.  I’d have sworn that it was a strong mature English cheddar.  Mmmmmmmmmmmmmm.
I’m starting to lose my resistance to becoming vegan.  And Eva is responsible!  Next the biryani, my favourite indian dish, so fingers crossed.

Eva this is great in all four parts.  I normally resist commenting on recipes as I can never resist changing this or that.  But today we had lots going on so I stuck to the recipe.  I got the sauce and the cheese done early.  The crepe batter I only left for 20 mins but the little tester worked fine.  I did add a red onion to the spinach.  
My vegan wife loved all four elements.  She found the sauce exquisite (no exaggeration) and I thought the cheese was better than my former almond cheese recipe.  Really cheesy.  
I’d recommend these need eating out the pan (immediately).  Or maybe when we have more than two I need to experiment with cooking and keeping the crepes hot without them drying (any thoughts).  
But great recipe.  Can’t wait to try more from the serious chickpea.
Oh my… just heavenly!!!  Definitely going to make these… thank you for the recipe!!  For the crepe base too!! <3 <3
thank you!

hi
love your recipes! what could i use instead of tofu? i dont use soy,, 🙁

thecuriouschickpea.title: Roasted Sweet Potato and Farro Salad with Garlicky Chickpeas
comments: This dish came together so easily and was out of this world good! The combined sweetness of the potatoes with the garlic and salty chickpeas, topped with tangy dressing was sublime!
Looks absolutely wonderful, and so flavorful!
I love the presentation of this dish, I could devour this entire plate in minutes! seriously though, amazing recipe, and that lemon vinaigrette sounds so perfect

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Mango Tarts with Vanilla Pastry Cream
comments: This is a little bit of an out of left field question but would this recipe work with soaked macadamia nuts?

thecuriouschickpea.title: Crispy Kale, Roasted Tomato, and Vegan Chicken White Sauce Pizza
Vegan Gochujang Bean Burgers
comments: These are hands down the best veggie burgers I have ever made or tasted. So so good. Great texture and the flavor is out of sight. I added some miso paste and a small amount of rice vinegar to the ‘batter’ and also used fresh garlic and a bit of turmeric and ginger and did half and half chickpea/ref. flour. Topped with kimchi and avocado as suggested. I will be making these for the rest of my life!!!
Oh, this is an interesting combination of flavours – can’t say I’d ever heard of gochujang before. These burgers look amazing!
We have been OBSESSED with gochujang!!! I think I know what we’re having for dinner today!!
These veggie burgers truly looking mouth-watering, incredible, love that you added kale to the pattie, this is a MUST try
I have never tried gochujang yet but it sounds so flavorful! Can you share the brands of gochujang and kimchi you used? Thank you Eva…off to read Cup Of Kale’s version now ?

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Garlic White Sauce
comments: @Colette, I’ve frozen this recipe multiple of times… I actually always make a double batch and freezer it in small quantities for pizza sauce
This was incredible !!!
Made this last night for my homemade pizzas – it was easy and delicious. I recommend it to all. I did not soak the cashews at all – Just used my Vita-Mix and it works great.

Used ghee instead of vegan butter. Oh. My. Goodness! I used this as a pizza sauce for a veggie pizza and could not hold back from eating a few spoonfuls in the process! DELICIOUS!!!!
Do you use raw or roasted cashews? Thank you.
This is seriously so delicious!! I was eating it by the spoonful! Can’t wait to use it for pasta and it’ll mix so well with a red sauce!! Thanks for the yummy recipe!!
This is my family’s go-to white sauce recipe for lasagna! We love it!!
Hello, could I use cashew butter from a jar instead of cashews? ^-^

I was making this for later in the week, but it was so good I abandoned my active dinner prep and used this instead. It did make a lot. Like another commenter, I wonder if it will freeze well? Any idea?
This is the most amazing sauce ever!  I use it on pizza, chili, burritos, etc.  For the latest batch, I roasted the garlic which made it even more yummy!♥️♥️♥️
The garlic white sauce recipe was amazing. I had to make it for the mushroom pizza and both recipes are winners. Can’t wait to use the remainder of the garlic sauce for pasta. Yum!

Thank You
