thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Chipotle Mac and Cheese with Spicy Tempeh Crumbles
comments:
Thank you so much for this incredible recipe!  You made my day! I have made several vegan Mac and cheese recipes only to be very disappointed.  My whole family loved this and it seriously took care of our cheese cravings (giving up cheese has been the hardest part of becoming vegan for us). It’s surprisingly easy to make and so worth it! I will make this again and again. I used tofu instead of tempeh and it was very delicious but had to bake longer.. Looking forward to trying with tempeh.
Thank you again ?

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Potato Leek Soup
comments: I used 1 cup of unsweetened cashew milk at the last 5 minutes of cooking instead of raw cashews. Very creamy and delicious. Will definitely make it again and again. So easy, simple and fast.

A great warming soup for a cold day.  Here it is chucking it down and a bit on the cold side.  This soup served with fresh crusty bread went down a treat.  The nuts added something but I’m not sure I could describe it – but certainly for the better.  Another hit from Eva who’s rapidly turning into my favorite vegan recipe source.
Hi Eva, many thanks for your lovely recipes. Potato and leek soup is one of my favourites. I’m looking forward to trying it with cashews. Do  i need to soak them before adding to soup recipe?
I am always looking for new soup recipes, and this one looks and sounds amazing! plus I just love leeks

thecuriouschickpea.title: Vegan Malai Kofta: Indian Dumplings in Curry Tomato Cream Sauce
comments: I don’t ever comment on recipes, but I needed to here. I’m a clumsy cook, but after I made many mistakes in this process, I have to say that this is a sensational recipe. One of the best things I’ve cooked. Love it so much.

This is my whole family’s favorite, it’s so flavorful yet mild that even my little ones ask for more! I fried the first few times then tried baking, and was really impressed with how well they still came out! They reheat perfectly in the air fryer the next day too. Wanted to finally leave a comment today as I pull up the recipe to make a celebratory last-day-of-school dinner!
Ok I never comment on recipes but this was just too good not to brag.  Everything had so much flavor and even my picky toddler needed more.  Definitely the new family favorite.

It looks delicious and am looking forward to making it. But, would it be possible to list metric measurements as well. I am always confused on whether pounds refer to Imperial pounds or American pounds! It could make a substantial difference!

Amazing. I’ve made it twice now and it’s a big treat. We make basmati and flat breads for the side so it becomes a big thing, but just *this* dish by itself isn’t as time consuming as it originally seemed!
Is it possible to cook the dumplings in an air fryer?

my dumplings didnt turn out so well.  I used arrowroot I dont know if that makes a difference.  They are really sticky, almost gooey and they are not frying up as pretty.  Could I add some flour to it (almond or chickpea) to make it keep its shape better?
Hi! I am in the process of getting the ingredients and I cannot wait to make this for my family and friends here in Torino. Will let you know how it goes 🙂

I’ve been making this for the last few years, but sorry to just now be doing a review. Hands down my favorite dish!  It’s got everything – spice, fragrance, crispy-crunch, creaminess and its healthy to boot!  I order kofta when dining out where I can, but none has compared to this.  Make it according to the recipe, but it won’t mind being fussed with if needed.
@April Rain, I often make the kofta mix the day before. I just cook from cold.
@Kathryn Hallor, I don’t peel my potatoes and mash the tofu on the pulse setting of my food processor to cut some time.  I also like to cook the potatoes the day before.

hi there! i’ve made this recipe before and absolutely loved it 🤩
i am making it this week for my externship assignment at work, and was wondering if you think the kofta mix would hold up raw if prepped the previous day? i will test a batch out tonight but was just curious. 
thank you!

I was excited to find this recipe, I used to love Malai Kofta, but vegan recipes usually had squash which I don’t like. I also don’t like tofu (a picky vegan for 16 years, it’s terrible!), but these didn’t taste tofu-y at all. I had a 300 gr box of firm tofu and maybe 75gr of silken tofu, so I used both. Only needed 1/4c of cornflour and they turned out really nice with that very long bake at high heat. We found the flavor very low key, so making them again, I would kick up all the spices by quite a bit. Definitely a keeper though. Thanks.
I made this tonight and it was phenomenal!  If you are thinking about making this please do.  It was so delicious!! Thank you so much for a great recipe.

I almost never leave reviews on food blogs (or anywhere really), but this is one of the best recipes that I have ever made! I could not believe that I had made something that tastes like it could be served at a restaurant. This is one of my favourite recipes of all time and have already made it multiple times. If there are any leftovers (rare), it also makes a great hiking snack (packed separately and using the sauce as a dip)!! Thank you so much for this recipe!

Made this and loved it!!!
One thing I did change was that I didnt have regular yellow potatoes (went to grab then from the pantry and they had loooong roots…lol) so I used steamed sweet potatoes and man, it was divine! I also couldn’t find fenugreek, so omitted it, and it was still so good. Highly recommend. I went the baking route, finished in my air fryer and the kofta was great!
Thanks for this recipe.

I love this recipe! So does my non vegan husband and family! Can these be frozen? I’d like to make up a big batch and have extras for a quick dinner. I’ll freeze the sauce prior to adding the coconut milk.
I want to prepare this for my son’s birthday . My question is do I have to crush the frozen peas or do I add them as a whole ? Thank you
Could I use squeezed okara for this instead of tofu? Always desperate for ways to use it up!
So good, sauce is awesome

PS
we did think that they were maybe missing a sweet note so next time we’re also going to add some raisins 🙂

Made these for the family last night and they turned out perfect!  Although not strictly vegan my hubby doesn’t eat land animals and is lactose intolerant so avoids dairy.  I also am keen to transition to a more plant based diet so vegan versions of our favourite meals are great for easing us all into healthier eating and these Malai Kofta certainly fit the bill perfectly!
Recipe came together easily – I used my potato ricer to mash the potatoes and the tofu and the kids rolled the koftas.  I choose to deep fry the balls at the temp specified in your recipe and they held together perfectly and came out lovely and crunchy on the outside and deliciously creamy inside.  I followed the suggestion of serving the koftas and sauce separately meaning the balls stayed nice and crisp and we all agreed they were amazing.
Seems like a recipe that would freeze really well to.  Next time I’ll be making a double or triple batch, lightly frying the balls I wish to freeze, laying them on a tray to freeze they packing in vacuum bags to freeze long term.  That way I should be able to finish cooking the balls in the oven (if I had an air fryer that would be even better I think) and simply reheat the sauce in a pot for a super fast and easy busy day meal.
Thanks for a great recipe!!  Looking forward to trying some of your others.

This is most delicious! Thank you for sharing.
I baked the kofta. The sauce is amazing. I am going to use the sauce recipe for my next go at butter chicken.
Happy New Year.

THIS IS AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS!!! 😀
We used the air fryer for the dumplings for 11-12 min. and they turned out so perfectly! I’m in love with the flavors!!! Thank you for this recipe!

Hi,
Can you freeze the dumpling mixture? Thanks!
Hello! This recipe looks great! Quick question – can I use dry peas instead of frozen ones? If so, should I cook them first? Thanks!
Thanks, I went ahead and purchased Yukons.  Great recipe.  Thanks!
Anyone try this with regular Idaho potatoes?  Have them on hand, but no Yukon.
This was so delicious! My non-vegan family loved it, too! I baked the kofta and they were light and fluffy and went perfectly with the curry sauce. Thanks for the recipe!
Can I mix the tofu and potato, leave it in the fridge overnight, then bring to room temperature and fry the next day?
Delicious! Tofu & potatoes make the perfect combination for vegan malai kofta. Love this recipe. Thank you.

I deep  fried several kofta balls that looked like they were crisping nicely but then fell apart when I tried to turn them… the dough also stuck to the bottom of the pan something awful. Then I reread the temperature for the recipe and realized I was frying them at 250 instead of the 300 to 350 degrees per the recipe.  Such a sad waste of the first bits of dough.  But once I corrected the temperature everything came out beautifully, soft on the inside crunchy on the outside and oh so tasty!!   I made both fried and baked kofta.  I probably left the baked kofta  in oven a bit too long as they flattened out and also had a “hollow” center.  They were also very crunchy  on the outside. They wound up looking more like a cookie than a meatball. Probably not ideal shape & texture, but very tasty in their own right. (Could probably serve as a crunchy appetizer…..The next time I make the baked ones  I would follow the temperature and time more carefully as I think I may have baked them a little too long.. I made the sauce the next day and reheated the kofta  in the oven on a baking tray.   I have never had kofta before, so I can’t compare, but I have to say everything tasted  fabulous!  I would give this 5 out of 5 stars and would 100 percent make these again!!! Thanks for a great recipe!!

Hi, this was delicious, I am making it for the second time today after my daughter requested it for her birthday dinner after she had it the first time a couple months ago!  It tastes so much like my favorite Indian restaurant’s version of this dish!   However, I have to suggest you revise the preparation time.  I’m not an inexperienced or inefficient cook, this is my second go at this recipe, and I have just completed making the balls and it took me a full hour to make and get them in the oven.  Peeling potatoes, mashing them up and mashing up the tofu, not to mention forming the balls–I can’t imagine that anyone could do even this part in just 15 minutes!!!  I assume I could make the sauce while they bake (I’m going to make the sauce a bit later) but even so that would take a full hour and a half of active time to get this meal on the table.  Nonetheless it’s well worth all the time and effort!
I can’t believe how good this is! Even baked, the kofta were still fluffy. I’m so glad I came across your site. Thanks a million!

Hi Eva, could you use chick pea flower instead of corn flower?
Many Thanks
Raj
??? this is amazing thank you for sharing!!

I made this and it was terrific. I used no oil and just 1/4 cup corn starch (as opposed to 1/2 cup) and the  dumplings held together just fine.  I recommend making a double or even triple batch of the sauce because I had way more dumplings than sauce with the above recipe.
This looks great! Just curious though, if you want the tofu smooth, why not use silken tofu?

I made this today and I’ve never left a comment on a recipe before. Although my baked koftas flattened in the oven (like cookies, I assume because it was too wet) they were delicious and the sauce was brilliant. My entire family couldn’t stop eating them including my picky preschooler who kept eating them from my plate. Thank you for this and I plan on making many more of your dishes.

This looks amazing!! My mom is going to make this & I’m so excited! I will let you know how it goes 🙂 
p.s. all the recipes on here look incredible! You’re an amazing chef.
You’re a fantastic cook.

i made this tonight and used a little oil for baking.  It was amazing! My husband and I both loved it and even my mother in law (who eats very little) kept eating and eating!  I will definitely be making this again.
I can’t wait to try this, it looks delicious! Is it necessary to put oil on them before baking?
This is a great recipe, I have made a few times now, shared the recipe with friends at work, they love it too!

Hi… I run a charity group providing fresh cooked, nutritionally balanced, tasty hot lunches ( vegetarian) to children in low decile ( poor) schools… we have been going for 6 years providing approx. 1000 meals / week ( all cooked on the same day and delivered to various schools)…The last day of term we like to do something special for the kids and was searching on internet for inspiration and found this recipe for kofta malai… Of course ,I will need to multiply the recipe by 100x ( for example the 1/4 cup cashews in the sauce becomes 3.5kg cashews) but I am excited to try this out with the kids next week and expose them to new flavours… I will combine it with a rice dish and a cake or trifle for a complete lunch… I will use homemade panir ( milk curd) instead of tofu because of cost considerations.. anyway, thanks for the recipe and your website..I let you know how it goes!
If you have s few minutes and would like to check out more of our lunch in schools program in NZ, there is a short documentary here https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=IxkgG6FNYg4&t=287s
Many thanks..best wishes…buddhi
wooooow,amazing dish.greetings from israel

Thank you for this recipe! The sauce is so good! I did something a little different for the kofta – instead of potatoes, I used yuca. And instead of frying, I added some coconut oil and cooked in the belgium waffle maker.

Rolled in Panko, good idea! I’m going to try that next. I agree, Kristine, this is better than eating out! 
Great recipe, thecuriouschickpea!
Maggie

This sauce!! OMG, it’s so easy and so good. I brought some to work and my co-worker talked about it all shift. Even better the next day. This whole recipe is kid friendly and decently easy. Thanks so much!
And my toddler loves them!

I have made these multiple times and they always come out great! I have even frozen some of the dough when batch cooking, and although it thaws a bit soggy, the kofta balls still come out of the oven with the perfect texture, you just have to work quickly with the dough to get it into the oven.

Hi! I made this beautiful recipe last night. The sad part was i didn’t have heavy cream or kasuri methi (i added fenugreek seeds instead) but it still turned out good but every time i took a bite, i kept thinking that something was missing!! Is heavy cream absolutely necessary for this recipe? if yes, can you suggest some substitute for it?
Thank you! 🙂

I’ve made this twice now. The first time I didn’t have the fenugreek leaves and it was good, but tonight I added the leaves and wow! What a difference! This is absolutely delicious. Thank you so much for sharing!

I went vegan (from vegetarian) about eight months ago and malai kofta/paneer makhani sauce was the one thing I’ve been desperately craving ever since. When I came across your recipe, I wasn’t sure what to expect and was a bit doubtful that it would taste as good as the real thing, but I decided to give it a try and it was AMAZING! If I didn’t make it myself, I wouldn’t believe it was vegan. Thank you so much for filling this void in my life 🙂

Made the Malai Kofta and it was delicious. Especially the creamy sauce. That was as good as the sauce I get at my favourite Indian restaurant . Going to try making the naan next
Thank you

This is an excellent dish, so thank you for sharing!! My husband who is not vegan loved it so much he ate it three days in a row until all kofta were gone. Although the kofta and sauce was delish, seeing the picture of your balls, I know that mine did not cook properly. I meant to deep fry and tried following the recipe which says to put 2 inches of oil in a pan on med-low. I must have ended up doing more of a pan fry because the outside wasn’t a deep golden brown and pieces of the kofta fell off into the pan during the process. I think that next time it will require a higher temp – maybe more like a med-high and more oil so that the entire ball is submerged in oil.

I made a half recipe tonight and it turned out great.  I did bake the koftas rather than frying, but otherwise (almost) followed the recipe as written.  I did soak the cashews, as I worried they might not blend well.  i also sauteed the onion a bit before adding the tomatoes.  Lastly, I added some roasted jalapeno (I had half of one in the fridge I needed to use) and some red chili pepper in place of the cayenne and was quite happy to have a very spicy tomato gravy.

I just made this tonight! We loved it. All had seconds. I doubled the cayenne based on the author’s comments but otherwise did the recipe as directed. It took me quite a bit longer than the recipe indicated, but it might go faster the next time. I may make the meatballs the day before another time. But there will be a next time!
I made these yesterday since we did our official Christmas dinner a few days ago. These are delicious! And the sauce! To die for! I want to put it on everything from now on!
This was soooooo good! It’s going into the regular dinner rotation. Thanks!

My husbands favorite Indian dish is malai Kofta but I am allergic to dairy. I made this last night and everyone in the family LOVED it! so tasty. I fried the dumplings. I think I may serve them on the table to be made one at a time because that first one- with the outside crispy and the inside soft was so amazing. After a bit the sauce makes them soft. Still good…but man that first one!
Thank you!
I like the idea of a vegan dish. Could one not make this with a vegan ricotta? The recipe sounds delish. Cannot wait to try it. Yummy

I forgot to rate it!
5*

Meant to say super delicious**
I read the other comment about adding more arrowroot powder so will try that! 
🙂

Hey, I made this last night and it was upset delicious. However, I tried both baking and frying the kofta and they didn’t turn out writhe times. When frying they just kind of stuck to the bottom of the pan and mostly fell apart even though I did roll them into a ball/little patty. When I baked them the insides were mostly hollow. They browned on the outside but the insides must have leaked out. Would I just need to add more arrowroot powder and make them firmer? Thank you for this amazing recipe!

Was very excited to try this tonight, but for some reason all the kofta completely fell apart when I fried them. Before I  put them in the pot they were perfect little balls, so it should have worked. I ended up throwing all of it away and just buying veggieballs from the  store. We made this tonight….it was amazing! Enough for tomorrow. We will definitely make it again. ….loved the flavors. Accidentally put in astofaeda instead of fenugreek….and then added it after all. Still tasted ok, I think. Thanks so much…. hoping to try out some of your others

Thank you for this recipe!! I have made it on 2 occasions and has gone down a treat both times. I had a friend who would usually turn down a meal without meat say it was the best curry he had ever eaten.
I substituted half the potato for sweet potato, twice the amount of cashews and chilli flakes for some heat x
This dish was absolutely amazing!! Thank you for sharing!

Thank you for the recipe
I did have an issue with it though. The dough for the koftas came out way too wet and I had to add a lot more cornstarch. I’m thinking this is because I don’t have a scale so I had to estimate my tofu and potatoes, or because I processed the entire dough mixture instead of mashing the potatoes by hand.
I deep fried the koftas and they stuck to the bottom of the deep fryer basket. Also, some of them burst open with a loud pop! I suppose the pressure from the heat became too much for them?
The sauce came out well. It was easy and came out tasting pretty similar to sauces I’ve had at Indian restaursnts even though I couldn’t find the fenugreek and omitted it.
I’m going to try this recipe again but using a scale and not processing the dough
My recommendations are to add raisins and cashew pieces to the kofta dough. They need more texture and flavor
The best kofta I’ve had has raisins in it and the sweetness really complements the savory flavors well
Do you have any other recommendations for fixing the mistake I made ?

This is absolutely delicious! Fancy, but fairly easy to put together. The sauce is so good and the potato balls are crispy and delightful
Would highly suggest making!
Hi Eva, thanks for the great recipe! I just ate it all and it was so delicious and creamy and tasty… lovely!

I’m sitting waiting for the  kofta to bake and if they aren’t finished soon the sauce is going to be gone!  It is absolutely amazing!   We like things a little spicy in my house so I added some extra cayenne pepper. I could seriously eat it all!   Can’t wait to taste the kofta!

As a vegan, a major miss has been Malai kofta [that and shahi paneer too 😉 ] Just finished eating this for dinner! It turned out phenomenally. We added a bit more cashews for extra nuttiness. The winning aspect was the kofta!  The consistency was perfect. Thanks so much for blessing our taste buds with this dish!
Thank you so much with this recipe! I made the sauce today (with potatoes, peas and paneer instead of the dumplings) and I loved it.

I want to attempt these in my air fryer. I just made some wonderful falafel in it, which worked out great, so I began thinking, why not malai kofta too?
I love malai kofta, and really miss not eating it since becoming vegan. Your recipe has great comments, so I trust your spice mix! Often Indian recipes online don’t taste at all like restaurant food, but yours looks great!
Thanks!

I really want to try this durng the weekend! But I want to ask if the kofta balls are mixed in a food processor or just mixed by hand? My family loves this recipe! Aside from Vegetable Korma, this Malai Kofta is my kids favorite dish! I add raisins to the veggie balls to sweeten it up. Tonight will be my third time making this recipe!  It’s our go to Birtbday dinner recipe! Thank you so much!

comments: I made this tonight using homemade gnocchi and Miyoko’s cultured vegan butter. I don’t know if I did the browning correctly because the butter sort of “foamed” a little when it melted, but, regardless, the end result was delicious! Will definitely be making this again.

comments:
This was the best. I’ve made it several times now, once with cashew milk and that was almost as good as coconut milk.
Does anyone know if it freezes well, specifically how is the tofu when it’s thawed?
This turned out amazing!! Thank you for the recipe, perfection!!

I made it last night!
It was delicious and great for week nights!!
I used store bought curry and didn’t verify the flavour first. I thought 6 tablespoons was a bit much so I reduced it to 3. Thank goodness because it was pretty hot! Happy i didn’t put any extra hot pepper in there! I added eggplant and snow peas as I had some that were just going to go to waste otherwise. I think eggplant fits really well in this curry!

That recipe is a keeper ? will do it again!
Absolutely delish! Made this for dinner last night and it was a hit!!! Thank you for this great recipe.

thecuriouschickpea.title: Homemade New York Style Bagels
comments: This is my go-to recipe for bagels. I love them and so does everybody who has tried them.

This was my second attempt at bagels and the first time following this recipe. I weighed the ingredients and loosely followed the instructions – I kneaded the dough longer than instructed and followed a different boiling recipe. The oven temps and times were off, the bagels didn’t rise well and the golden color was really difficult to achieve. This adaptation needs work, I appreciate the author’s feedback in other comments but it seems this recipe is still a work in progress. I won’t use this recipe again, I’m sorry to say.

I tried this recipe because it included instructions for a food processor. I misread the recipe and used 1.5 cups of water which seemed fine. Just out of the oven.   Taste great.   Next time I would make 10-12 bagels as they are rather large.

I’ve made these 3 times, doubling the last 2 batches, and the last batch was on point. My dough puffs up in the fridge then collapses with the slightest manipulation, so I reshaped the entire batch, and let it rest another 20 minutes, and boiled them, they puffed up beautifully, and puffed up even more during the bake. I am liberal with the olive oil I use to prevent drying out or sticking to the parchment paper, and I use the same parchment paper throughout and for the bake, the bagels sort of fry a little in the olive oil, which adds a wonderful crunch and a whole new wonderful dimension to these already great great bagels.

This is the recipe/blog-post that keeps on giving, isn’t it?
I’m born and raised in the New York metropolitan area and have eaten dozens and dozens of NY bagels. I worked in a bagel store for most of a school year, a very long time ago, when I was 16, bagging and making sandwiches – not baking.
Now living in the Boston area where there are bagels but they’re not the same. My brother lived here for a while: he accurately described the local bagels as “rolls.”
I followed the recipe, scaling up 150% so that I’d get a dozen, with two days in the fridge before baking, using a scale to measure, and malt syrup that was available at Whole Foods.  Used bread flour from Lindley Mills (purchased 25 pounds when bread flour was scarce at the beginning of the pandemic).  This dozen, the first I’ve ever made, included two everything, four onion, and six sesame.  Had a bite while still warm last night and then toasted, straight out of the freezer, this morning for breakfast. Perfect!!!  Thank you, thank you, thank you! I expect that I’ll be making these again.

This is a great recipe, as long as I immediately put the dough in the fridge overnight for the first rise in the fridge, and barely do any second rise at all in the morning (just enough time to form the bagels and boil the water/heat the oven). Otherwise they overproof and fall when I boil them, but the “reverse” way has worked perfectly for me.

I’m still confused by the first two steps:
combine ingredients in a food processor, let rest for 10 min
Then Add dry ingredients and wet together in a stand mixer.
Isn’t it just take dough from food processor and move to stand mixer or table?

I’ve made these bagels twice now. The first time I didn’t time things well and forgot to preheat the oven, so I think they sat out too long and ended up completely flat (although tasted delicious). I tried for the 2nd time today and while some turned out better, some were still pretty flat. I’m not sure what part of the process I need to improve on? Again, they taste perfect, but just hoping for a higher bagel.  Thanks!

FYI – a cup of water weighs 236.588 grams.  1 1/3 or 1.33 cups of water weigh 315g, not 350g as the recipe calls for. 350g/236.588g=1.48 cups of water. This really points to the problem with volume measurements.
To follow up, for measuring small amounts a jewlers scale works well, ~$12 on Amazon. Mine measures to a 100th of a gram, granted a bit overkill.

These are very good bagels. 
For those the have trouble finding bread flour you can use vital wheat gluten(VWG), VTW can be found in most chain grocery stores. This makes it possible to have excellent results with AP flour. I even use it with bread flour since it’s my opinion bagels work even better with high gulten flour which runs around 14.2% protein. Bread four runs around 12-13%, AP around 10-11%. The formula for caculating how much VWG you need is as follows, make sure you use paretheses as shown: ((target protein percent) – (source flour protein percent))*(flour amount)/(VWG protein percent – source flour protein percent).
If you want to be very precise take total flour minus the amount of VWG

So I tripled the dough because I’m making minis for a baby shower (51-52 gr each).
Goal was to boil and freeze to bake off the day of the shower but I did a test run on 3 for baking.  Used a pizza stone at 450 with and without a pan of water.  We decided that those baked with the water were less crisp so I will be ditching the water for the final baking.  I noticed that  https://food.briess.com/  recipe uses 2 types of syrup and AP rather than bread flour.  I would not change the flour but have come to the conclusion that what is missing from most other bagels is the complexity of flavor from the malt syrup so I’d like to try some combinations, and also try and completely replace the yeast with sourdough starter as the long rise/sourdough/syrups all appear  to impact the complexity of the flavor.  Will be searching for starter/kg flour ratios…. great bagels and I think there will be the hit of the shower!

I think it is important to mention that this can be done first because I am tripling the recipe and would not have room for the formed bagels overnight.  My Kitchenaid did fine with the dough.  I am making mini bagels as I am helping out with a baby shower and no local place- we are looking at a 15 mile radius, makes minis.

Thank you for this superb recipe that encapsulates so many important points regarding bagel making. After repeated disappointment with store bought which are little more that donut shaped Wonder bread or overpriced and usually only OK bagel shop bagels, I have gone all in on home baking. . 
I just tried it and agree that adding baking soda and salt in addition to malt syrup to the boil gets the perfect crunchy but thin crust. I had a few suggestions about which perhaps other readers can comment:
1) Since bagels have a bit in common with pizza dough in terms of preparation and ingredients, I have substituted 100g of ripe sourdough starter for 80g of the water, since sourdoughs develop well with long, cool retards. You can cut the instant yeast a bit if you add sourdough
2) I have had good luck with Korean rice syrup (ssalyeot) that also has a high maltose content. Maltose has a distinct taste unlike sucrose (sugar), melibiose (honey) and most other sweeteners or syrups, and does not contain any fructose. These are available inexpensively at Korean markets in LA or in general at Asian markets or on Amazon.
3) Most baking flours contain malt that includes enzymes that break down starch into sugars, improving yeast action and rise. You can overdo it with diastatic powder but 1/2 tsp seems to work well. Please understand that non-diastatic syrup or powder is for flavor whereas diastatic powder contains enzymes. You can purchase a decade’s worth of diastatic malt powder (1.5 lb.) on Amazon for ~$10. Malt powder is also great for baiting mouse traps!
4) Flour is key to all baking. For bagels, I prefer General Mills All-Trumps that has 14.2% protein, which is higher than bread flours. The protein is important to get the right ‘chew’. Some of the other strong flours such as KA Sir Lancelot are almost as good.
5) If you regularly make bagels, the stiff, low-hydration dough will overtax most home mixers. I have had good luck with the Swedish Ankarsrum which was able to
6) The flour:water ratio varies according to flour type and humidity. For bagels, you want a smooth and elastic dough that is barely sticky. Adjust with small amounts of flour or water accordingly.
7) Silicone mats work great and avoid any use of oil. For the overnight retard, simply cover the bagels with plastic wrap that will adhere to the mat around the bagels, forming a seal.
8) I bake at 475° with a stone on the bottom and a pan. I allow about 45 min to fully heat the stones and the oven. I pour boiling water into the pan just before closing the oven door.

I’m an amateur baker and I’ve been making Peter Reinhart’s bagels from “The Bread Baker’s Apprentice” for about 2 years and have always had mixed results, mostly because of the bagels flattening out. I was so excited to read your explanation on hydration in the recipe as it answered that question, I’ve done this recipe twice now and they’ve been more consistent. My one problem is getting the toppings to stick to the bagel. I use both malt and baking soda in the poaching liquid, but once they’re through baking, and light handling to slice them, knocks 85% of the toppings off. The right way to make it is use soggy bagel dough and let rest for two days in the frig. It’s the two day bagel whe dough needs to mature to taste like a classic bagel. I never flour the table I want the dough wet unlike pizza dough which I throw into the AP flour to roll out. For bagels you roll the dough into balls and then cylinders to length then connect the ends into a loop. Then put three fingers into the hole roll once back and forth to meld the seam together. Place into a pot of boiling water boil on both sides 45 seconds to 1 min. They must float upto the surface or they won’t be airy after baking. Then place on wooden plakes to dry off one side then place them on to it’s other side on sheet pans till golden. These steps don’t include the sprinkle toppings such seasame , garlic etc. Cut and smear on some cream cheese or butter. You should hear the crunch when you bite down and the inside should be airy and moist. I may have missed a few things but keep looking.
